results.title: Cricket 97: Ashes Tour Edition for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert and manual in a cardboard box
results.brief_description: A sequel to Cricket 96 and an expansion to Cricket 97, Cricket 97: Ashes Tour Edition further improves on the series’ graphics, featuring stadiums rendered in three-dimensions, a series first. Cricketing legends Ritchie Benaud and Ian Botham have been added to provide commentary and are featured in full motion video interludes. The Ashes Tour Edition introduces enhancements such as real players’ names and stats, a larger stadium, an instant replay function, and minor gameplay improvements.

results.title: Emulation of Cricket 96 for DOS
results.brief_description: A sequel to Super International Cricket, Cricket 96 allows the player to set up the field, bowlers and batsmen and play either test or one-day matches. It improved on the graphics of its predecessor and features eight teams, although it forgoes official team or player licensing. However, many of the in-game players have recognizable real-life counterparts, albeit without their actual names.
results.description: A sequel to Super International Cricket, Cricket 96 allows the player to set up the field, bowlers and batsmen and play either test or one-day matches. It improved on the graphics of its predecessor and features eight teams, although it forgoes official team or player licensing. However, many of the in-game players have recognizable real-life counterparts, albeit without their actual names.
description_for_label: A sequel to Super International Cricket, Cricket 96 allows the player to set up the field, bowlers and batsmen and play either test or one-day matches. It improved on the graphics of its predecessor and features eight teams, although it forgoes official team or player licensing. However, many of the in-game players have recognizable real-life counterparts, albeit without their actual names.

results.title: Cricket 96 for DOS
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description: A sequel to Super International Cricket, Cricket 96 allows the player to set up the field, bowlers and batsmen and play either test or one-day matches. It improved on the graphics of its predecessor and features eight teams, although it forgoes official team or player licensing. However, many of the in-game players have recognizable real-life counterparts, albeit without their actual names.

results.title: Fleetwood Mac (this is the one)
results.brief_description: In a year many spent locked inside, Nathan Apodaca gliding down a highway on a skateboard, drinking Ocean Spray and lip-synching Fleetwood Mac’s ‘Dreams’ was the tonic we all needed.

constellations_primary.name: Film and TV dreams
constellations_primary.description: Fleetwood Mac's 'Dreams' coasted its way back up the charts 40 years after it was first released, thanks to Nathan Apodaca's joyous viral TikTok, but Fleetwood Mac (and Stevie Knicks) have been main staples of screen culture for decades.

results.description: In a year many spent locked inside, Nathan Apodaca gliding down a highway on a skateboard, drinking Ocean Spray and lip-synching Fleetwood Mac’s ‘Dreams’ was the tonic we all needed. The 22-second viral video sparked countless imitations, with Apodaca’s wholesome performance giving the world some long overdue joy.

results.title: Where the Desert Meets the Sea
results.credit_line:
Cinematography by Brad Gibb 
Edited by Ben Lane  
Special thanks to Wayne Miller
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 4:12 min
results.brief_description: Shelley Ware’s film Where the Desert Meets the Sea (2020) tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.
results.description:
Shelley Ware is one of Australia’s most respected female sports presenters. She is a Yankunytjatjara, Wirangu and Kokatha woman, well known for her role on the SBS program Marngrook Footy Show. Currently, Ware hosts the AFL.com web show ‘Colour of Your Jumper’. Ware is also an educator, and her film Where the Desert Meets the Sea tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.

“This is a story of my Country and why the game of AFL and the Koonibba Football Club are so important to me. I share the stories of my people, as a teacher and sports presenter, so that our children, can be what they see.” – Shelley Ware

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 3 - Yellow
results.creator_credit: G-O-D/ G=enerator, O=perator, D=estroyer, Adem Jaffers and Frank Peppard
results.brief_description:
Please note, this video may potentially trigger seizures for people with photosensitive epilepsy. Viewer discretion is advised.

Cyberthon V: Spectrum Yellow was broadcast as the third of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason and Kim Bounds) Surfis (Dom Owen and Peter Bourke), Mad Club (Danny Slim, Richard Cheese & Cracko), Christopher Coe (Digital Primate), 2120 (Claude Younge Jnr) and Phuture (Crissie Sievers).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 3 - Yellow is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

Cyberthon V: Spectrum Yellow was broadcast as the third of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason and Kim Bounds) Surfis (Dom Owen and Peter Bourke), Mad Club (Danny Slim, Richard Cheese & Cracko), Christopher Coe (Digital Primate), 2120 (Claude Younge Jnr) and Phuture (Crissie Sievers).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 3 - Yellow is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Darling Darling
results.credit_line:
Gabriella Hirst
Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound, 25:30 mins.
SanDisk Memory Card, gold leaf, in collaboration with Barbara Dabrowa, AGNSW Senior Conservator of Fine Arts – Frames
Courtesy the artist
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound and gilded SD card
results.brief_description:
Darling Darling presents two contrasting but linked responses to the idea of conservation. One side of the screen shows the meticulous care taken to restore WC Piguenit’s prized 1895 painting of the Barka-Darling River, The flood in the Darling, 1890, while the other side reveals the present-day neglect of the river itself. Excess upstream water diversion and climate change have contributed to severe water scarcity and mass fish kills in recent years.

In composing her shots of the river, Hirst references Australia’s beloved landscape painting tradition, and colonial-era artists like Eugene von Guérard, John Glover, Conrad Martens, Nicholas Chevalier, Ludwig Becker and of course, WC Piguenit. While their romantic paintings capture a sense of nature as awe inspiring, they also served the more material purpose of framing resources to be owned and exploited by European settlers, a visual expression of the concept of terra nullius.

Darling Darling invites us to question the role played by Western visual art traditions in shaping the value systems that allow such an extreme environmental crisis to unfold right before our eyes.

Gabriella Hirst (she/her) is an artist. She was born and grew up on Cammeraygal land (Australia) and is currently living between Berlin and London. She works primarily with moving image, performance, and with the garden as a site of critique and care. Gabriella’s practice and research explores connections between various manifestations of capture and control – spanning plant taxonomies, landscape painting, art conservation and nuclear history.

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021
